title: Cameron delivers response to Isis hostage threat at PMQs: Politics live blog | Politics | The Guardian
summary: pmqs - most popular tweets , and verdict from the twitter commentariat .

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: david cameron has vowed that islamic state ( isis ) will be squeezed out of existence '' , and promised to build a coalition in the region against it that can not be mistaken for a western-led intervention .
labour has accused the government of being all over the place '' on domestic security .

after ed miliband used pmqs to expose policy differences between cameron and nick clegg ( see 1.18pm ) , a labour source said : the prime minister confirmed he wants to go ahead with relocation powers .
that is very different from what the deputy prime minister said earlier this week .
in the prime minister 's answer on stopping british citizens returning to the country , he still could n't be clear on what 'exclude ' actually means .
it would be accurate to describe the government 's position as all over the place on these matters .
it is five days since friday and there is no clarity , no detail and no timetable .
the lib dems are playing down talk of a rift .
( see 2.07pm . )
ed miliband speaking during pmqs cameron has accused countries that pay isis for the release of their hostages of funding terrorism .
at pmqs he was asked about this by sir menzies campbell , the former lib dem leader .
campbell said : you will be aware that often when these cases arise , there 's a suggestion that ransom should be paid .

should those who advance that case take account of the fact the money achieved by ransom is not distributed , for example , among the impoverished citizens of gaza , rather it is used to purchase weapons , to finance the training and maintenance of those who are willing to use them and otherwise to advance the malevolent objectives of terrorism ?
cameron said campbell was absolutely 100 % right '' .

he went on : there 's no doubt in my mind that the many tens of millions of dollars that isil has raised from ransom payments is going into promoting terrorism , including terrorism affecting our own country .
at the g8 , i launched an initiative to try to get other countries to sign-up to a very clear doctrine that in the case of terrorist kidnap , no ransom should be paid .
britain continues with this policy , america continues with his policy but we need to redouble the efforts to make sure that other countries are good to their word .
yvette cooper , the shadow home secretary , has hinted that labour could support britain taking part in air strikes against isis .
the government is not proposing them , but it has not ruled them out either .
speaking on the world at one , cooper said labour 's opposition to air strikes against syria last year did not mean that it would oppose a bombing campaign against isis .
i think the situation is very different from last year , from syria .
the whole situation is obviously extremely complex .

last year the concern was that there was n't a clear objective at the time that the prime minister seemed to be rushing to take action without a clear sense of objective or what action we would take that would be workable and would meet those objectives at the time .
i think , therefore , the government has been right to take a more measured approach this time , to look very carefully at all of the issues .
and we 've supported the government .
obviously ministers have said that airstrikes are not on the table at the moment .
of course , no government should ever rule out any option , and it 's right to always look at all of the options .
jack straw , the labour former foreign secretary , said earlier he favoured britain joining air strikes .
cameron has said the government needs to tackle those who promote the extremist narrative '' , and not just extremists who advocate violence .

in comments suggesting he supports the michael gove drain the swamp '' approach to extremism , he told mps : what i think we need to be absolutely clear about is it 's not enough to target those who preach violent extremism .
we need to go after those that promote the extremist narrative and life-view that gives the terrorists and the men of violence support for what they do .
it 's not unlike the cold war , where we did not just pursue those who wanted to do us such harm .
we also had to challenge all those who gave them succour .
cameron has said the commons will hold a day-long debate on the threat posed by isis , and related foreign affairs issues , next wednesday .
philip hammond , the foreign secretary , has said the government will examine every possible option '' to protect the british hostage threatened with death by isis .
michael fallon , the defence secretary , has said nato countries need to spend more on defence .
in a speech he said : let me be very clear about the uk 's position .
it 's time now to toughen up so that nato can deal with the aggression and the threats that we face .
that means rapid reaction forces that are worthy of the name , that means better sharing of capability , and it means the first ever public commitment to increase defence spending .
that will demonstrate to all those who threaten us that the state of our transatlantic bond is strong .
the unpredictable and uncertain threats of today and tomorrow demand nothing less than that .
michael fallon cameron has said that councils should take a firmer line on sacking officials who fail to tackle child abuse .

after diane abbott raised the matter at pmqs , he said he agreed with her that authorities needed to look at the contracts they offered senior executives to ensure they could be removed if necessary .
he also said that the chair of the national inquiry into child abuse would be named within days .
cameron has said the decision to issue an arrest warrant for the parents of ashya king did n't chime with a sense of common sense '' .
speaking at pmqs he said : to be fair to the authorities involved in the case of aysha king , they all want to do the best for the child .
that 's what they are thinking of .
but i think what happened was that decisions were taken that were n't correct and did n't chime with a sense of common sense .
that , fortunately , has been put right .
what all of us in public life and public offices have to do is examine what the legal requirements are , but also make a judgment , and those judgments can sometimes be all-important .
theresa may , the home secretary , the home office is going to publish a mobile phone theft index to give consumers more information about which phones are most likely to be stolen .
she made the announcement in a wide-ranging speech on the future of policing .
the home office is publishing a mobile phone theft index .

rain/epa nicola sturgeon , scotland 's deputy first minister , has said public opinion appears to be shifting in the run-up to the independence referendum in a similar way to before the 2011 scottish parliamentary election .
she said : i definitely sense a shift .
this is a referendum , it 's not an election , but certainly i remember very well how that felt in 2011 when you just got the sense that something was moving in terms of opinion .
and i feel that now .
but alistair darling , leader of the better together campaign , said the no camp would win .
responding to a report in the herald newspaper quoting a better together insider saying it 's possible we 'll lose '' , darling replied : that 's rubbish , we will win . ''
gq magazine has defended its decision to give former prime minister tony blair its philanthropist of the year '' award after criticism from mps .
i 've got a meeting this afternoon , so that 's going to be all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
the lib dems are playing down talk of a rift with the conservatives over two aspects of the anti-terror package .
( see 1.18pm . )
this is what the party is saying about including relocation in the reform of tpims .
the issue of introducing relocation powers remains under discussion in government .
we have agreed to look in detail at the options available to us .

the independent reviewer of terrorism legislation , david anderson , whose views we respect , recently recommended that the government look at locational constraints that can be put on tpims suspects to make it easier to disrupt their networks and to reduce the risk of absconding .

as a result , the liberal democrats are willing to look in more detail at options , including at whether the use of exclusion zones under the existing legislation could be expanded to meet the concerns that anderson raises .
and this is what the party is saying about the plan to stop british-born terror suspects returning to the uk .
this issue remains under discussion in government and we have always said that we would be prepared to sign up to something that was both legal and practical .
this is a very legally complicated issue and needs to be examined very closely .

documents.title: pmqs - most popular tweets , and verdict from the twitter commentariat
text: and here are some of the more interesting comments on pmqs from westminster journalists .

isabel hardman ( @ isabelhardman ) not sure the libs will be happy with that line on relocation powers for tpims unless they 've now reached agreement # pmqs john rentoul ( @ johnrentoul ) nick clegg completely impassive throughout cam 's confirmation that relocation power of control orders would be restored # pmqs tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) an impressive pmqs performance by @ twitterid miliband .
statesmanlike on is threat , but deftly political too exposing coalition mess on terror laws .
anushka asthana ( @ skyanushka ) ooh scottish nationalists in commons a bit rowdy !
they guffawing , heckling , gesturing .
they having a ball at tightening polls .

# pmqs faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) peter hain calls for air strikes against isil in syria and government engagement with iran : # pmqs george eaton ( @ georgeeaton ) peter hain a reminder that many of the most passionate interventionists are on the labour benches .
# pmqs and here are the most popular tweets including pmqs '' ( excluding pure news ones ) .
according to tweetdeck , these have all had at least 50 retweets .
from newsnight 's chris cook chris cook ( @ xtophercook ) i 'm confused by # pmqs .
two adults appear to be having a conversation .
from huffington post 's mehdi hasan mehdi hasan ( @ mehdirhasan ) cameron says he wants to see democratic governments across the middle east .
that must have come as news to bahrainis , saudis et al .
# pmqs from gordon mcdougall , an stv news producer gordon mcdougall ( @ gordonmcdougall ) ooooh at pmqs today david cameron said we ran away from a debate .
wait 'till you see our response on stv news at 6pm tonight .

documents.title: my pmqs verdict
text: pmqs verdict : thankfully i do n't have to try to call a winner today because this was one of those cross-party consensual exchanges were david cameron and ed miliband were , predominantly , both articulating the same message : robust opposition to islamic state ( isis ) and all it represents .
potentially i thought we might learn a bit more about what both leaders feel about britain getting involved in air strikes , but on this topic the exchanges were utterly fruitless .
( all we know is that cameron is downplaying the prospect of the british military bombing isis , but is n't entirely ruling it out .
as for miliband 's position , that 's even more opaque . )
but miliband did quite skilfully drive a wedge between cameron and nick clegg on two key aspects of the anti-terror package announced by cameron on monday .
on another day he might have followed his questions with a ( justified ) riff about coalition splits .
today was n't the day for that , but sometimes pmqs is all about storing up ammunition for the future .
the first issue raised by miliband was the government 's plan to beef up terrorism prevention and investigation measures ( tpims ) .
miliband asked whether this would include allowing relocation '' ( telling suspects they have to move - or internal exile '' , in the view of critics ) as part of the tpim regime .

yesterday , in an interview on the today programme , clegg made it clear that he was unhappy with relocation and that he wanted to toughen tpims instead by using more exclusion measures ( preventing suspects from going to some places ) .
in his response to miliband , cameron confirmed he did favour relocation , but in combination with exclusion .
the key is i think to put the desires and advice of david anderson , who is the independent reviewer of terrorism , to put those into action .
what he 's spoken about is some combination of exclusion and relocation and it is that that needs to be introduced into the terrorism prevention and investigatory measures .
i think we should try to do this on a cross-party basis to send the clearest possible message , and i think that urgency is the order of the day .
the second issue raised by miliband was the plan to allow the authorities to stop british-born terror suspects returning to the uk .
here the split with clegg is much clearer .
asked about this yesterday , clegg said : at the moment it is not obvious what one can do in a way which is consistent with our legal obligations .
but when miliband asked cameron if this proposal was legal , he insisted it was .
i do believe it is legally permissible , but it is going to take some work for this reason .
we already have the power when people are trying to return to the uk .
if it is a foreign national , we can exclude them - even if they have lived in this country for any number of years .
if it 's a dual national , you can strip them of their british citizenship and exclude them from the country .
if it is a naturalised citizen , you can , under our new laws passed recently through this house , you can strip them of their british nationality .

but i do believe there is a gap where you have someone born and raised and a british citizen - rather like the individual we discussed on monday from high wycombe , saying he wanted to return and do harm to our country .

of course , the best thing to do is gather evidence , prosecute , convict and imprison - but i do think there may be occasions where we need to exclude , so therefore we should fill that gap in our armoury .
i believe it is legal and possible to do it .
political journalists spend much of their time on split-ology , asking questions designed to expose policy differences between politicians who are allies .
today miliband did our job for us , and he did it very well .
david cameron at pmqs
hooray !
i 've achieved lasting fame .
the conservative mp christopher pincher has just used a point of order to ask john bercow about comments attributed to a source close to him in a guardian story i wrote last week .
but it turns out that my prominence is limited .
bercow said he had not read the story , and would not comment on it .
sir menzies campbell , the lib dem former leader , says if ransom is paid to hostage takers , that money is used to promote terrorism .
cameron says campbell is absolutely right .
some tens of millions of dollars have been raised for isis this way .
he got the g8 to agree action on this .
america and britain do n't pay hostage takers .
he wants other countries to follow , he says .
and that 's it from pmqs .
i 'll post a summary soon .
labour 's sarah champion asks about the abuse in rotherham .
when will the government appoint the chair to the national abuse inquiry ?
cameron says theresa may is leading a committee of ministers .
the announcement of the chair of the abuse inquiry will be made in the coming days .
the police sometimes felt these people were beyond the pale , he says .
that offends our sense of decency .
james gray , a conservative , says there should be a full , two-day debate on foreign affairs .
cameron says gray is right about the challenges facing the world .
there will be a full day 's debate next wednesday , he says .
labour 's diana johnson asks about a constituent stuck in northern iraq and unable to travel home .
cameron says he will look at this .
he commends the work foreign office officials do .
he says he takes a personal interest in hostage cases .
chris kelly , the conserative mp from the 2010 intake who is standing down , says he supports attempts to remove passports from british jihadists .
cameron pays tribute to kelly and the work he 's done .
people in dudley ( kelly 's seat ) and elsewhere think people who go abroad to fight should lose their nationality .
labour 's peter hain says isis wo n't be beaten without air strikes in isis .
ultimately isis poses a big threat to countries in the region than to us .
cameron says assad 's brutality has helped to generate the isis regime .
what britain wants are democratic governments in the region , he says .
we should support moves towards a democratic transition in syria .
karl turner , a labour mp , asks , with the clacton byelection coming on cameron 's birthday , if cameron is expecting any other birthday surprises .
cameron says he expects many surprises on his birthday .
he does not want people to tell him what they are .
john hemming , a lib dem , says families like ashya king 's are increasingly going abroad because they think they will get a fairer deal from the family courts abroad .
cameron says hemming could raise this in a commons debate .
jim shannon , the dup mp , asks if it is time for additional measures against isis .
cameron says britain is working with the kurds and others to allow isis to be beaten back .
sir edward leigh , a conservative , says losing scotland would be a national catastrophe .
not enough has been done .
he appeals to the three party leaders to drop everything over the next two weeks and to campaign .
cameron says the three leaders all agree on this ; not just that the uk is better off with scotland , but that scotland is better off in the uk .
lindsay roy , a labour mp , says alex salmond has said that an independent scotland would default on its share of the national debt .
camerons says this has been one of the most chilling things said in the campaign .
scotland would have to pay a punitive interest rates .
that would have an impact on people 's mortgages .
jacob rees-mogg , a conservative , says if hampshire police can misuse a european arrest warrant , is n't there a risk other countries will also misuse them .
cameron says we have to think what might happen if a terrorist is on the run , and britain wants to catch him .
this is not an imaginary situation ; it happened after 2005 .
he wants to be able to look the british people in the eye and say he kept them safe .
alasdair mcdonnell , an sdlp mp , asks if the modern slavery bill will be amended to include child guardians .
cameron says the government will look at this .
on the aysha king case , he says the authorities wanted to do what was best for the child .
but the decisions taken were not right , he says .
matthew offord , a conservative , asks cameron to condemn boycotts of israeli goods , saying they promote anti-semitism .
cameron says the government does not support boycotts , or anything that delegitimises israel .
you can criticise israel without being anti-semitic , he says .
angus robertson , the snp mp , asks if cameron will honour his promise to take part in a tv debate with undecided voters .
cameron says he offered them a date , but the broadcaster did not accept .
richard drax , a conservative , says net migration at the current level would fill a city the size of leeds every three years .
we should have a visa-only system for arrivals , including for those from the eu .
cameron says he has done a huge amount to restrict migration .
some 700 bogus colleges have been closed .
we need to do more .
freedom of movement is important .
but it is not an unqualifed right , he says .
when new states join the eu , transitional controls should not be time limited .
labour 's diane abbott says directors of social services pay no penalty for ignoring child abuse .
often they go on to better jobs .
do contracts need looking at ?
cameron says he agrees entirely .
what we 've seen in rotherham is shocking , he says .
he has asked theresa may to chair a team of ministers looking at lessons that can be learnt .
councils should ensure that contracts allow people to be removed .
martin horwood , a lib dem , says some people in the middle east share britain 's desire for democratic change .
wo n't they find britain 's position inconsistent ?
cameron says he does not agree .
he is not a naive interventionist '' .
but he engages with states to promote regional stability .

snap pmqs verdict : a predictably statesmanlike performance from both leaders , which revealed nothing new about whether cameron or miliband might back air strikes , but which did enable miliband to subtly drive a wedge between cameron and clegg on two key anti-terror proposals .
miliband asks if it is legally permissible to stop terror suspects returning to the uk .
cameron says he thinks it is permissible .
the law already allows dual nationals and naturalised britons be be excluded .
on monday he discussed someone from high wycombe who says he wants to return to do harm .
he believes it will be legal to prevent people like this returning .
miliband asks if cameron will beef up the prevent programme .
cameron says the government has tried to divide up the different elements of prevent .
but it is not enough to target those who preach violent extremism .
the government has to go after those who promote the extremist narrative '' .
it is a bit like the cold war .
miliband asks what plans cameron has to use britain 's chairmanship of the un security council to address this .
cameron says there is an opportunity to marshall international support for the idea that isis must be squeezed out of existence '' .
miliband turns to domestic issues .
can cameron confirm that he will reintroduce relocation powers for suspect terrorists ?
and when will that go ahead ?
it will go ahead , says cameron .
david anderson proposed a combination of relocation and exclusion .
he hopes there will be cross-party support .
urgency is necessary .
ed miliband says he joins in the universal sense of revulsion at the murder of steven sotloff .
events like this must strengthen , not weaken , our resolve to stand against them .
cameron has labour 's full support .
cameron says these people must understand we will not waver in our opposition to terrorism .
miliband asks if cameron agrees britain has a humanitarian and security interest in defeating isis .
what is being done to mobilise countries in the region to defeat them ?
cameron says miliband 's approach is entirely right '' .
this can not be solved by foreign intervention .
this appalling organisation must feel the full pressure of regional condemnation .
britain must use all the assets it has .
if we continue in this way , we will ask how others in the neighbourhood can play their part .
stephen metcalfe , a conservative , asks about the long-term economic plan .
cameron mentions today 's gdp revised figures from the ons .
the long-term economic plan is working , he says .
labour 's jim cunningham says cameron used to say he wanted the tories to stop banging on about europe .
what has changed ?
cameron says a lot has changed in europe .
he wants to give people a say .
david cameron starts by condemning the sickening and brutal '' murder of another american hostage and expressing his shock and anger '' that it appears to have been committed by a briton .
but this country will never give in to terrorism , he says .
there is no way to appease isis ( he uses the term isil , but our style is isis . )
if isis think this will undermine britain , they are are wrong .
it will reinforce britain 's determination to stand up to them .
he is sure a united message will go out from the commons .
christopher hope ( @ christopherhope ) expectant tone in the commons as mps gather for a sombre # pmqs .
phil hammond whispering urgently to david cameron on the front bench .
isabel hardman ( @ isabelhardman ) how will ed miliband attack at pmqs in a few minutes ' time ?
here are some thoughts

documents.title: cameron at pmqs
text: david cameron will be taking pmqs in about 10 minutes .
he will use this opportunity to give his response to isis 's latest beheading of an american hostage , and its threat to kill a british hostage .
my colleague matthew weaver has been covering this story all morning on a separate live blog .

here 's his summary of the latest developments.. barack obama has vowed that the us will not be intimidated by threats from isis after the militant islamic group murdered a second us journalist , steven sotloff .

obama said the us was repulsed be the group 's barbarism and that it would track down those responsible.. obama insisted that the us did have a strategy for tackling isis , but called for international support in fighting the group in iraq and beyond .
we have got to make sure that we are organising the arab world along with the international community to isolate this cancer , '' he said..
the uk government will examine every possible option '' including air strikes , to tackle the threat posed by isis , according to the foreign secretary , philip hammond .
he also confirmed that an unsuccessful attempt was made to rescue hostages , including a briton threatened by isis in the latest video..
both hammond and the us government said the video of sotloff 's murder appeared to be genuine .
there are reports that it was released earlier than isis had intended.. obama ordered 350 more troops into iraq , hours after the release of the latest beheading video .

the new deployment was intended not for a combat role '' , the white house press secretary josh earnest said in a statement , but to augment security at the baghdad embassy and associated support facilities '' .. an investigation is under way to establish whether the man dubbed jihadi john is behind the second murder after a british-accented man was shown in the video de the killing sotloff .

security sources said that although there were similarities between the voice on the film that emerged on tuesday and that de the murder of james foley a fortnight ago , the figure is largely hidden in black clothing..
journalists have paid tribute to sotloff who reported on some of the most unstable and dangerous locations in the world .
steven embodies what it takes to report from combat zones , '' said bill roggio , managing editor of the long war journal .

documents.title: theresa may 's speech - summary
text: as alan travis reported in his preview story , theresa may , the home secretary , used her speech to the reform thinktank today to suggest that police , fire and ambulances services will have to integrate in the future .
in the event , she devoted one sentence of the speech to this , but it may turn out to be the most important revelation .
she also announced plans for a mobile phone theft index .
but there was plenty more in the speech too .
here 's a summary .
i 'm afraid the full text is not available on the home office website yet .
may said the police , ambulance and fire services would have to integrate in the future .
this was because further spending cuts were inevitable , she said .
what 's striking is that we have been able to make many of these changes not despite spending cuts but because of them .
this is important , because the need to go on reforming will not end with this parliament .
with a still-large deficit and a record stock of debt , there will need to be further spending cuts , as even labour acknowledge .
so in policing in the future , i believe we will need to work towards the integration of the three emergency services .
she said the home office was going to publish a mobile phone theft index to give consumers more information about which phones are most likely to be stolen .
police forces tell us that recent rises in theft from the person , for example , were in part driven by the theft of smart phones by organised criminal gangs .
these gangs targeted specific venues , like concerts and festivals , to steal smart phones on a massive scale .
the phones were then often sent overseas where they are reactivated and sold .

there is of course an operational response to this kind of criminal activity , which should be left to the police , but the home office has also been working with industry to find new ways to stop the reactivation of phones overseas , thereby killing the criminals ' export market .
and we can go further .
a decade ago , the car theft index contributed to a fall in vehicle theft by allowing consumers to make informed choices about which models of car to buy based on their likelihood of being stolen .
today i want to announce my intention to do the same with mobile phone theft .
working with industry and the behavioural insights team at the cabinet office , the home office is developing proposals to further prevent mobile phone theft .

these include steps that consumers can take to improve personal security , industry innovation to develop new security features she said she wanted to go further '' in terms of opening up senior police jobs to new recruits .
she said she wanted police forces to use body cameras more often , and to become fully digital '' by 2016 .
we should go further with direct entry .
we should use technology she said there were six drivers of crime '' and that she wanted the home office to learn more about them .
that is why i have set up a team called the crime and policing knowledge hub inside the home office .

understanding that overall crime levels are only the net result of millions of individual decisions in millions of different contexts , officials have been working to identify and understand the six main drivers of crime in this country .
we believe they are alcohol , drugs , opportunity , the effectiveness of the criminal justice system , character and profit .
if we can understand each of these drivers better , if we can understand how they relate to one another , we should be able to devise better policy to prevent crime occurring in the first place .
she said car thieves are increasingly using technology , not stolen keys , to take cars .
for example , working with the metropolitan police we have discovered that more than a third of vehicles stolen in london do not involve taking the owner 's keys .
instead , car thieves might break into a car and programme a new electronic key .
they might use sophisticated devices to 'grab ' the security coding when the owner uses their key so they can use it themselves .
and there have been reports that they could even use 'malware ' to commandeer vehicle systems via satellites and issue remote demands to unlock doors , disable alarms and start car engines .

because we have this understanding , we can now work with industry to improve electronic resilience , include this kind of resilience in the vehicle 's overall security ratings , and work out the extent to which the same threat applies to other physical assets such as building security systems .
she said one reason she was so keen to tackle domestic violence is because it is not just a crime , but a driver '' of crime too .

it is well known that children who are brought up in violent households are more likely to become violent themselves later in life , so domestic violence she described labour 's approach to micro-managing crime as complete nonsense '' .
in march 2002 , he created five policing priority areas '' .

these places were as small and specific as camberwell green in southwark , the grange estate in stoke , little horton and canterbury in bradford , the west ward in rhyl and stapleton road in bristol .
the police in these places , labour decided , could n't cope with high levels of crime and anti-social behaviour .
so the solution was obvious .
if the police could n't do the job , the home office would .
if you lived on stapleton road in bristol , you could stop worrying because help was at hand .
a civil servant sitting in queen anne 's gate in london was ready to take charge .
the policing priority areas '' were not an aberration .
the 2002 police reform act required the home secretary , at the beginning of each financial year , to prepare a national policing plan '' .
the act said the national policing plan must set out the strategic policing priorities generally for the police areas in england and wales for the period of three years beginning with that year '' .
yes , you heard me correctly .

the home secretary and officials were n't just expected to know how to fight crime on stapleton road in bristol , they were expected to know precisely what local needs would be for every other community in the country , and that was , of course , complete nonsense , and it could n't be further removed from the approach we have taken to police reform in the home office since may 2010 .
jamie grierson ( @ homeaffairspa ) home secretary theresa may delivers speech on police reform # reformpolice
sorry the blog has been quiet for a while .
i 've been at a briefing , and i forgot to post a line saying i would be away for a bit .
in a moment i 'll post details of theresa may 's speech .
it 's interesting .
the office for national statistics has published a paper revising its growth figures for 1997 to 2012 ( pdf ) .
the paper itself is not for the faint-hearted .
here 's an extract .

the estimate of quarterly real gdp growth has been revised up on average over the period 1997 to 2012 by +0.02 percentage points , ranging from -0.7 percentage points in quarter 2 , 2007 to +0.7 percentage points in quarter 2 , 2008 and quarter 1 , 2009 .
the revised path of gdp confirms that the 'peak to trough ' of the 2008/09 economic downturn remains the deepest since ons records began in 1948 .
but the treasury is very pleased with the ons findings .
it says they show an economy that has been growing more strongly than previously thought , with almost every quarter under this government being revised upward '' .
here 's an extract from the treasury briefing .
the ons have significantly revised up the uk 's growth profile since the 2008/9 recession .
growth since 2010 is now 1 per cent higher than previously thought .

if current growth rates from 2013 onwards are applied ( which are yet to be revised ) then today 's revisions suggest that gdp has grown by 8.1 per cent since the first quarter of 2010 , compared to the 7.0 per cent previously thought .
this would be the third highest growth of the g7 ( ahead of france and germany but behind the us and canada ) .
by the end of 2012 the economy was -1.7 per cent below its pre-recession peak compared to the -4.0 per cent previously thought .

if current growth rates from 2013 are applied the uk economy would have passed its pre-recession peak in the third quarter of 2013 and would now stand 2.7 per cent above the pre-recession peak ( compared to the 0.2 per cent previously thought ) .
this morning downing street has announced the signing of a £ 3.5bn contract to buy 589 armoured vehicles .
it claims this will safeguard 1,300 jobs .
here 's an extract from the news release .
as the prime minister sets off to wales to host the nato summit , the government will today sign a deal for the next generation of world class armoured vehicles for the british army .

securing 1300 jobs across the uk , the £ 3.5bn contract for 589 new armoured fighting vehicles is the biggest single order placed by the ministry of defence for armoured vehicles for over 30 years and is an important part of the investment we are making to keep britain safe and to ensure our armed forces have the equipment they need to operate in an unpredictable world .
the contract for the scout specialist vehicles will be signed at general dynamics ' engineering hub in south wales .
it will sustain 300 jobs in wales .
the scout specialist vehicles ( sv ) are testament to the world class engineering skills in south wales and across the uk , helping to create the army 's first fully digitalised armoured vehicles .
for the record , here are today 's yougov gb polling figures .

labour : 35 % ( down 1 point from yougov in the sunday times ) conservatives : 32 % ( no change ) ukip : 15 % ( down 1 ) lib dems : 8 % ( up 1 ) labour lead : 3 points ( down 1 ) government approval : -24 ( up 1 ) according to electoral calculus , this would give labour a majority of 30 .

we 've got the first pmqs since the summer recess today and it will be dominated by what david cameron has to say about the government 's response to isis 's latest beheading of an american hostage , and its threat to target a british hostage next .
here 's the guardian 's main story with all the latest developments and here 's how it starts .

david cameron will set out the british government 's response to the threat to the life of a british man by islamic state ( isis ) at prime minister 's questions after an emergency meeting of cobra on wednesday morning .

government sources said cameron had known of the threat to the man 's life for many months so it will not change his short-term calculations , but the revelation of the threat to the public in the gruesome isis video is likely to put more pressure on the uk to join the air strikes that the americans have been conducting for weeks against isis in northern iraq .
cameron has already told mps he regards isis as a threat to the british way of life , and has not ruled out raf involvement in air strikes .
cameron is certain to confer with the us president , barack obama , at the nato summit in wales on thursday , both about the threat to further hostages and the wider strategy to combat isis .
obama is under intense domestic pressure to be more decisive and is considering whether to extend the air strikes to syria , the original base of isis .
my colleague matthew weaver is writing a blog focusing exclusively on this story .
i 'll be covering pmqs in detail , but otherwise i will be mostly be leaving it to him to cover breaking developments .
instead this morning i will be focusing on what looks like an interesting speech from theresa may , the home secretary .

as my colleague alan travis reports , she will argue that need for further spending cuts will necessitate the future integration of the police , fire and ambulance emergency services and the widespread use of body-worn cameras and smartphone apps by officers to save time .
here 's the agenda for the day .
morning : david cameron chairs a cobra meeting to discuss the reaction to the isis threat to kill a british hostage .
9.30am : theresa may delivers a speech on the future of policing .
12pm : david cameron faces ed miliband at pmqs .
around 12.40pm : mps begin a debate on a labour motion on class sizes .
2.15pm : mark sedwill , the home office permanent secretary , gives evidence to the commons public accounts committee about the reform of the uk border agency .
2.30pm : theresa villiers , the northern ireland secretary , gives evidence to the commons northern ireland affairs committee about on-the-runs '' .

as usual , i will also be flagging up any breaking political news , posting summaries with a round-up of all the day 's developments , and highlighting the most interesting political articles on the web .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
